result.execSummary:
The defendant Justin A Nickell was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Maintain Drug Trafficking Place, a class I felony, Wisconsin Statutes 961.42(1).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

parties.name: Barron County Clerk of Circuit Court

miscConds.notes: $250.00 cash bond applied. If probation or extended supervision is allowed to expire or is revoked with outstanding financial obligations, the supervising agent shall notify the court 10 days prior to the revocation or discharge and provide current financial information.  A civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of restitution victims and governmental entities for any balances due.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect all debt.  Attorney Fees To Be Determined.  Probation does NOT collect attorney fees.

Must obtain and maintain employment. 
Must complete any and all evaluations, counseling, treatment and follow-up recommended by Probation Agent.  Must submit DNA sample and pay the surcharge. Order for DNA given to the defendant in court. Must report to Barron County Jail immediately, to submit DNA sample.
AODA and comply with recommended follow-up treatment.

timeConds.notes:
Court grants work release. 
Jail credit to be held open - to be applied if revoked from probation. 

Court orders 15 days jail. The jail time may be served by 120 hours of community service work to be completed within the first six months.   If the defendant fails to perform the community service as ordered he/she must report to the jail as ordered with credit of 1 day of jail served for each 8 hours of community service completed.

Court orders 15 days jail. The jail time may be served by 120 hours of community service work to be completed within the first six months.   If the defendant fails to perform the community service as ordered he/she must report to the jail as ordered with credit of 1 day of jail served for each 8 hours of community service completed.

supervisions.notes: Court costs reduced to civil judgment.
